slides.title: Set-Theoretic Information Retrieval
slides.subtitle: Fuzzy Sets and Extended Boolean Models

content.text: Extending the rigid logic of the Boolean model to handle the ambiguity of natural language using Fuzzy Logic.
content.hook: Is a tomato a fruit? In Boolean logic, yes/no. In Fuzzy logic, it's 0.8 Fruit, 0.4 Vegetable.

content.text: Standard Boolean (AND/OR) has no notion of 'partial match'. If a document has 4 out of 5 query terms, Boolean AND rejects it completely. We need a way to 'soften' these operators.

content.definition: Fuzzy Set Theory: An element belongs to a set with a degree of membership between 0 and 1, rather than just 0 or 1.
content.text: In IR, a term characterizes a document with a certain degree (e.g., correlation factor). We use fuzzy operations (Min/Max) instead of logical AND/OR.

content.description: How a vague concept becomes a numeric relevance score.

content.text: Proposed by Salton et al. to bridge Boolean and Vector Space models. It introduces the 'p-norm' concept to control the strictness of AND/OR.
content.hook: It allows a query like 'A AND B' to act like 'Vector A + Vector B' (soft) or 'A intersect B' (strict) depending on parameter P.

content.text:
P = 1: Behaves like Vector Space (Sum).
P = Infinity: Behaves like Standard Boolean (Min/Max).
This allows tuning the system for precision vs recall.

content.description: Consider the term 'Fast Car'. Assign a score (0-1) for how well these cars fit the set 'Fast': Ferrari (1.0), Honda Civic (0.4), Bicycle (0.0). Now query 'Fast AND Red'. Calculate scores.

content.linkage: We've softened the logic. Now let's look at more advanced algebraic ways to uncover hidden meanings in text.
